We took the country tour which led us away from the city canals and included stops at a windmill and cheese/clog factory. So much fun, so glad we did it.

Great way to see the city surroundings with kids!!. We were 2 family with kids aged between 6 and 11, and we all had a blast!! Mike let us have a Bakfiet, and the kids took turns riding in it, and it was fantastic. Petra our guide was fun and informative, and better of all, the group was patient when the shorter legs were tired, Thanks so much!!!
Fantastic!!. Very interesting!! Great sights out of the city, cheese tasting, clog watching. Tour guide fab, great info and very helpful!!

Great way to see a bit of Amsterdam and the Dutch countryside. As with most bike tour groups, Mike's is staffed by a bunch of friendly, knowledgeable and laid-back twenty-somethings. Our guide, Petra, was excellent! As a native, she had a ton of information for us, which was relayed chronologically at various stops throughout the trip. We learned a great deal about the history of Holland, and also got to see a variety of locations in and around Amsterdam including a beautiful city park, houseboats on the canals, wilderness trails, dikes, traditional and contemporary architecture and a small dairy farm, which sells it's own cheese, as well as a variety of Dutch-made souvenir items. Bring a lunch (or snack) and water, because you'll stop at this farm for a break toward the end of the ride. (This is your only bathroom stop--I highly recommend using the bathroom at Starbucks or McDonald's before the tour, as the Mike's Bike's bathrooms leave a bit to be desired.) You'll get a short tour of the cheese-making and clog-making operations there, as well as a taste of their awesome kaas (cheese). For something like a Euro, fifty, you can also have an ice-cold can of Heineken (or two), which will taste amazing because: a.) You'll be thirsty from riding, and b.) Beer always tastes better in it's native country!By the way, be sure to volunteer to "bring up the rear" of your tour. You'll get your beer for free! My husband did this, and he did have to ride up to let our guide know that one of our group members was way behind (and possibly lost) after she stopped to take photos, but they found her quickly and all was well.Our kids (ages 12 and 8) did well on the tour, and enjoyed themselves, despite the humidity that day. The terrain is, as it usually is in Holland, very flat, and the wind was minimal. Though the ride is not strenuous, you will probably feel tired, but content, afterward if you are not used to riding for hours at a time.

Great Bikes, Great Guide, Great Day. I was so happy to find Mike's Bike Tours in Amsterdam. I generally like to book all my tours in advance but found that none of the other tour companies fit with MY schedule. And I am so glad that I did! We showed up (after getting horribly lost -- damed crazy streets!) just in time, jumped on our Electra Townie bikes (for anyone who rides a bike, they would know that that is a great bike) and off we went into the countryside. We toured all of the places that everyone else tours, I have got to say, but that is just what we expected; the windmill, the wooden shoe and cheese factory, all the places visitors to Amsterdam want to see. Loved the cold beer at our stop! Thanks! Great, informative guide. And reasonably priced. So stop booking those tours and creating a "schedule!" Show up at Mikes a their designated time, and off you will go on an great adventure!

Loved it. The highlight of my trip to Amsterdam!!!. The things I wanted to do in Amsterdam (aside from the obvious) was to ride a bike (the Dutch way), see a windmill and the countryside, and to visit a cheese and clog factory. The countryside tour with Mike's Bike Tour allowed me to do just that! I got there around 11:20am and the tour usually starts at 11:00am so I just made it to the end of the basic introduction but luckily, was allowed to join the group. The guide, Stewart (sorry if I recalled the incorrect name) was very friendly, approachable, knowledgable and experienced. He gave the group lots of information on the history of Amsterdam and travel tips throughout the tour, and even a few restaurant recommendations. I'm not an expert bike rider but never felt out of place throughout the tour - I loved every minute of it. All the staff was really friendly and helpful - one of them let me take a photo of their beloved plant when we returned our bikes! There was another bike rental/tour near the hotel where I stayed but after reading the reviews, I knew I had to go with Mike's Bike! It was truly a great way to see Amsterdam and it was a great day out. Do not miss out on this if you're in Amsterdam! It's a must do. I would do it again the next time I'm back!!!

An awesome 4 hours. This was my favourite day out in Amsterdam. It was brilliant to do after a few days in the city as it takes you out down the Amstel and you get to see the beautiful countryside. I was worried about riding in the city and with a big group as I haven't ridden in YEARS but the bikes were easy to ride and comfy! A must do!
Not to be missed. The bike tour is a great way to see a bit more of Amsterdam and enjoy the countryside sights. I'd recommend it to anyone as a great way to spend 4 hours in the city.

Don't worry about the rain...just go. Postponed Country trip (E22 each) until following day because of rain but need'nt have bothered as full capes provided which kept you (almost) dry.Tour ran from 11.30 to 15.00 and our guide was Pete who was laid back to the horizontal.Our pre trip briefing was done by Karl, a fellow Brummie and fellow old boy of KE Camp Hill.Took rolls with us for the cheese factory and bought some of the Gouda which they cut the rind off and sliced for us for E8. In the wet however nowhere to sit and eat and so took back to hotel. Good cheese.Weather was horrendous but everyone took it in good humour.The whole set up of Mike's Bikes is super friendly and I cannot recommend them highly enough.Good quality bikes and well maintained with seven gears for the hills!

Country side tour Rocks....Petra as guide is amazing!. I would totally recommend to go on the "mike bike tour" of the Amsterdam country side. I would recommend this over and above the city tour!I went ton Sunday and it was amazing....so much fun and learned a lot! You also get to see other types of things (as opposed to just the city and buildings).Our travel guide (Petra) was phenomenal....so if you can, try to find out if she will be conducting the tour because she is so funny and really makes the tour even better. She makes history fun:)The visit to the cheese farm was also nice, and the cheese that we tested were delicious.The tour is about 4 hours, which includes a stop at a cheese farm. Pack some bread or food for when you stop there because you will be very hungry. You can always pack bread and buy the cheese there:)

Fun way to see Amsterdam like the locals do it.. Thought it might be enjoyable and interesting to see Amsterdam on two wheels like the locals do it! Mike's Bike Tours was a really kick back operation. We just did the City Sights Bike Tour which was a really nice way to see parts of Amsterdam which you might miss just walking around. Our tour group was kind of large with 12-14 people and we only lost one person briefly :-) The tour lasted about three hours and we saw so many sights and different sections of the city. We liked the Joordan Area the best.There are bikes everywhere in the city, be sure to watch out for fellow local bikers who know the road rules much better than a tourist. We would totally recomend renting out a bike for an afternoon with this company.

DO IT. This is the 3rd bike tour I've done at Mike's in Amsterdam-Stuart has been our guide on 2 of these trips and his knowledge and obvious love of history is unparelleled. If you are visiting Amsterdam, Mike's bike tours is a great way to see the main sites and get a brief history of the city. The country tour is fun too-you don't see as many historical sites but still learn a lot about the city and what makes it so great.

Windmill Bike Ride in Amsterdam - A Fun Ride. While in Amsterdam for a conference, I had the opportunity to take the country bike tour with Mike's Bike Tours to see a windmill and a cheese farm/wooden shoe factory. We were given an orientation to biking in Amsterdam and how to survive as well as what to do if we were to get lost or separated from the group. Then we were off on the tour with stops in Vondel park, the houseboat community, the sports park, and finally the windmill where we had a group photo taken. We then biked to the farm. The tour guides made it an interesting tour with informative tidbits about the history of the Netherlands as well as modern day things to avoid in order to survive a trip to Amsterdam. Overall, it was a fun adventure. I never really found out who Mike was and it didn't really matter. All the tour guides were a bit eccentric but interesting. Overall, it was a fun way to see the sights and learn about the history of Amsterdam. Incidently, you don't pay until you return if you are satisfied! Will definitely do another tour!

The best way to see the country side. For 4 hours (about 23 KMs) we rode in the country side enjoying the view and the great explanations from our guide. In the middle we stopped at farm and a funny local farmer showed us how they make cheese and wooden shoes. The bikes were a top condition and it was well worth the 22 EUROs.

Must do for active Americans. My husband and I started our tine in AMS with Petra'scity tour on Mike's Bikes and couldn't gave been more pleased. So fun, funny, informative! LOVED it and learned so much/saw so much if this smzinv city. Stay close to her for her quippy comments... And great rice table rec after the tour! 5*
Fantastic way to see the beautiful country side.. Went on the country bike tour a few weeks ago, I've done about a dozen since and Mike's Bikes Amsterdam still stands out as one of the best.

Fantastic tour and brilliant guide. Took the city tour on our 1st day - Stuart gave us lots of great advice on attractions to visit.
Liked the tour so much that we took the Countryside tour later on during our stay. Easy cycling and saw parts of Amsterdam that we would not have found by ourselves.

Great people, cannot rate highly enough. I have been on a fair few bike tours and I cannot honestly rate these guys highly enough. Amsterdam is famous for bikes, and they have enough bike tour and hire companies to match. Mike's is different, they are a small local business operating out of a single garage in the centre of Amsterdam. The assistants and guides are very easy going, such friendly nice and honest people.We took a bike tour of the city centre. No pre-booking needed, we simply turned up at the garage, they welcomed us and handed us some bikes. The tour itself was laid back and just perfect, a good amount of stops, with very informative information. Later in the tour we stopped off at a pub to have a beer with the tour guide before setting off again. The price was very good, only about twelve euros when we went, and discounts for students too.Overall, do not look elsewhere for bike hire or tours. Avoid the big tour companies, you cannot go wrong with Mike's, and they are so friendly!

Best way to explore the 'dam!. I really can't say enough good things about Mike's. The tour was extremely fun, educational (without being boring) and it was a great way to see the city of Amsterdam. Pip was our tour guide and he was so friendly, entertaining, and a great leader. I learned a lot from him! Not only this, but they were extremely helpful when I left a belonging in the office and I am overly satisfied with their customer service and willingness to help.Make sure you brush up on your quiz skills- and you'll receive a drink on them :)Biking is easily the best way to see the city and with a small group, you get to meet new people, get some exercise and explore. It was never too strenuous and not hard to keep up, just be cautious of the other bikers! I would recommend this to anybody. My only regret was not having enough time to do the country tour- I will definitely when I return.Thank you again, Mike's, for the best last day of my experience in Amsterdam!

Petra is a star. Omg this is the best bike ride I have ever been on and I think Petra made it she is so so funny. She had some much info on Amsterdam and showed us country side we would never have seen. We went to the clog and cheese factory which was interesting and the cheese was lush I could have eaten it all day, I would highly recommend this bike tour and if you get Petra you are in for a treat

Great day in the countryside. We selected Mike's tours based off of other positive reviews from TripAdvisor. We were glad we did. My husband and I haven't been on a bike in years, but this was a trip we were able to complete. We chose the countryside trip. Highly recommend this one. It is about 14 miles long over a four hour period. The countryside is beautiful. It was hard to believe we were so close to the city and yet felt so rural. We rode along the Amstel River for a long time and it was very peaceful. We then went to a family owned farm where they make their own Gouda cheese and wooden shoes, all of which is for sale in their little store. We then continued through some farms and lovely parks. Some people opt for the city tour; however, I felt it was somewhat dangerous in the city when we first got started and ended this trip. I felt much safer out in the country. There are many rules in the city that apply to bikes. The countryside is just quiet riding past the farms and trees. One important piece of advise, bring your own water and snacks. The ride started at 11am and doesn't end until aroun 3pm, and there are no stops for food. Also, water is a must. They sell some at the bike shop if you forget.

Great Way to See the City. With all the narrow streets , bike touring is a great way to see the sights and Mike"s is a cool operation. Very friendly easy going guide. Hard not to be easy going with all the coffee shops here:) Always loaded with local and historical info, the guides really do know Amsterdam. Stopped for a beer or two or three along the way. Great tour, lots of fun.

Mike's Bike Tours never disappoint. Mike's Bike Tour of the City of Amsterdam was fantastic, even if it did spit rain the whole time. Our guide Kate was from Dublin, but she knew Amsterdam very well. She was fun, excited, informative and friendly. I would highly recommend this tour as a way to get familiar with the city and it's many wonderful attributes.

Take up the opportunity to get some inside info on the city. Before going on this I was a little apprehensive, not about the city traffic particularly, more about fitness levels! However, there was no need to worry as it is a very easy cycle ride & more than a little exciting at times, especially at junctions.Very worthwhile & great value.

Great way to see the city and it surroundings. Exploring a city like Amsterdam by bike is the best thing to do. You get to see a lot in a little time and wherever you want to spend more time you can stop for as long as you want. So renting a bike was clearly set for us although we never thought about doing a bike tour. After discovering the city for a couple of days we wanted to see a bit more and decided to do the countryside bike tour. This was a great choice and we have had a blast. The tour first takes you through the city, along the river to the suburbs of Amsterdam. We stopped at a windmill and tasted cheese on a farm. The same family also showed us how to they make the wooden shoes. After this little break of about 45 to an hour the tour continued through the countryside around Amsterdam, again along a river with great houseboats and finally through some greats parks. We not only enjoyed the whole tour but it also gave us great ideas on what else to do in Amsterdam. If we did not had to leave the next day, we would have gone back to the big forest/park just outside Amsterdam.The best thing of the whole tour though was Petra, our guide. She is from Amsterdam and had apart from a great humour lots of stories and history to share with us. Definitely a great way to get to know an other city/country.

A great time!. This was a really fun few hours. We biked out of Amsterdam, into the countryside, stopped at a cheese factory / shoe factory (this was pretty touristy, but it was still interesting and it was a nice break in the middle of the trip), and then back through more countryside and park back into Amsterdam and to the shop.The whole vibe was fun, relaxed, having a good time. The guide, Pete for us, kept things going but in a friendly, relaxed way. He also stopped periodically and told us about the area and sights.We went with our two kids, our 13 yo son and 10 yo daughter and it was fine for them. I had to encourage her a few times to keep up, but it really wasn't a problem and she had a great time.After spending a lot of time standing in lines and looking at things (sites, museums, etc), it was really nice to get some exercise on a beautiful day while also seeing things.

Great time in a lovely city. If you're planning to visit Munich, put Mike's Bike Tour on your list of DOs. By bike you'll have an unique vision of the city. Also, you'll have the opportunity to have a lot of fun while getting to know better about the history of this almost 900 years old city. We joined the superior standard bike tour this morning and we highly recommend it. And if by chance you find out that Tonny will be your guide, don't hesitate: I'm sure you'll enjoy the experience; the guy is awesome!

Do a Bike Tour in Amsterdam. One of the best activities to do in Amsterdam is a bike tour. We did Mike's Countryside Bike Tour and it was fantastic! The route is flat and easy, and our tour guide, Petra took frequent breaks to fill us in on Dutch history. We start off in Amsterdam and ride through Vondel Park and into the lush green countryside along the Amstel River. We stopped by a cheese making farm and a Dutch wooden shoe factory. The cheese samples are delicious and fresh and watching them make the shoes was fun. Shoppers are welcome to pick-up some cheese, shoes and other Dutch treats! After a nice break, we hopped on our bikes to enjoy the scenic, quiet countryside. It's a nice break from the city streets and a great way to enjoy the afternoon. TIP: Bring a bag lunch/snack and water.

Fantastic tour - great experience and value. Went with my mum and sister and thoroughly enjoyed the whole tour. Pete was the guide who was excellent and gave us the right level of history and information on A'dam and the Netherlands. It gave us a real insight into the countryside and the clog/cheese man was brilliant - v entertaining. There was no hard sell in the shop which was great...bought quite a lot of goodies.Would highly recommend this, loved it!! (and so did my mum who had not been on a bike for ~ 20yrs!!)

Excellent city overview, easy ride, lots of Amsterdam's info!. I just finished the afternoon "City Bike Tour" about 4 hours ago (4 to 7 pm): I must recommend it as an awesome way to see & know Amsterdam. It was an easy ride since the city is flat - the only hills are the bridges.. about 2 feet high! Our tour guide was excellent, giving us a Master class about history, geography, sociology, architecture & useful tips of this beautiful & unique city. The bikes are pretty easy & friendly since they are regular street bikes so anyone can ride them, and for 18 Euros you get 3 full hours of exciting sightseeing and fun - just watch on the intersections because some bikers are a bit agressive.

Great bike tour for families. We want to do some biking while in Amsterdam, but were hesitant to hit the city streets solo with our 8 and 10 ten year old. To ease us into biking in traffic, we opted for Mike's countryside tour. It was perfect! We were lucky enough to hit a day with lots of riders and two other families so they put us in a group with just the families. Stewart was our guide and a good match for our kids. They all wanted to ride near him and he was wonderful about answering their questions and keeping an eye on them. The ride had enough stops that no one got winded, although the wind made it a bit challenging. Kids enjoyed city history, cheese tasting, and shoe demonstration, but some kittens on the farm were the hit. Highly recommend this for families. We now feel ready to try some solo biking, and we are very educated on city history.

Justg do It!. As a senior who doesn't exercise, I was a bit concerned about keeping up. Gotta say...this is a great way to get around the city and to learn Amsterdam history. We had no idea how near certain areas were until we biked around with our guide (Peter?). The group was mostly teens and twenty-somethings, but we all stayed together and looked out for each other. The city is relatively flat and the bikes have lots of gears. Don't fear...just go.

Great Tour. Pete was an excellent tour guide with lots of historical and amusing info about Amsterdam. It was a great way to get oriented in the city. However, I would recommend that you be very comfortable on a bike if you take this tour. The streets are busy and there are lots of obstacles.

Beautiful countryside. This is my second tour with Mike's Bikes and they're consistently great. They have the best tour prices in Amsterdam and the guides are friendly and knowledgable. The bikes are comfortable with wide seats and are easy to ride. Take the countryside tour and see an old windmill, a clog/cheese farm and the beautiful vistas around Amsterdam.

This tour is a MUST. We did this tour at the end of our trip and I wish we had done it on the first day. We learned so much history about Amsterdam and then got a great tour of the city. It's a great way to get an overview, and history, to help you decide what you want to spend more time doing. Or, if you only have one day in Amsterdam, this is the best way to get everything in! The guide was really informative and funny, and the tour was well worth the cost.

Excellent value, great experience, terrific guides...and fun!. Went on the countryside tour. For 22 Euro, we rented great bikes and were guided out of the city (given interesting tidbits of history along the way). We had a guide who took us to a windmill and also to a gouda farm and clog making shop. It was extremely informative and fun. The bking was not strenuous at all. It took about 4 hours and all the staff at Mike's Bike Tour and Rentals were very friendly and knowledgeable. The shop is very accessible just off Leidestraat. And if you went on this tour you could get a discount on a second day rental. I definitely would do this again...and apparently there are Mikes Bikes in other European cities.

Great way to get to know the city!!. I was in Amsterdam the last two weeks of May and decided to take the Countryside tour. What an experience! We had Mike himself as our personal tour guide! Great dude! Really funny! We would first go around the Amstel River stopping every now and then to get infomation, go to a windmill to take some photos and finally to a cheese farm Really funny guy...really good info! If you ever go to Amsterdam I highly recommend this tour. It's only 4 hours and you get to feel why bikes rule the place!

Fantastic tours - a real must in Amsterdam. Mike's Bike Tours were brilliant. We started off doing the City tour which was great - a perfect way to get our bearings. Petra our guide was certainly amusing and crazy! She was easy to follow - just looked for the bubble trail behind her.Had so mujch fun on the City Tour that we decided to do the countryside tour which was longer but just as enjoyable. We cycled along the Amstel River and into the country. Beautiful, quiet countryside - certainly nice to be away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Pete, our Guide was great and had loads of interesting things to say.Both tours were really good fun and a brilliant way to see the real city and also the countryside. Would certainly try another Mike's Bike Tours in another City!

So much fun. We took the country side tour and it was GREAT. I regret not doing it earlier in our visit. We got to see a lot and it was the guide did a really good job!! I would definitly recommend this to anyone going to Amsterdam.

Bike is the best way to explore Amsterdam, why not a guided tour?. After one day walking around Amsterdam, finding out it's not a huge town, we've chosen Countryside tour with Mike's bike tours.You can come just before start of the tour (in this case 11:00), do not worry, they have enough bikes. You'll see Amsterdam from a different view compared to walking in the centre along the channels. You'll ride about 20km in 4 hrs therefore you do not have to worry, especially since it's a flat land. You'll go through town, see the old wind mill, farm where cheese or clogs are done. BTW, cheese is great and you get it here cheaper compared to the same cheese sold in the downtown. Worth to buy it there. You'll have some more short stops, which are enriched by a great guide (Stuart looks to know more than locals :-)At the end, if you survive, you have to pay. The good thing is you get a discount for another tour or for bike rental. We've used next day ...

Laid back, professional, knowledgeable. I went on both the Amsterdam City Tour and the Countryside Tour and was highly impressed with this tour company. Don't judge a book by its cover, these guys come across as very laid back but they are all very professional and knowledgeable about the area. They are also very safety orientated. The only thing that I regret is that I didn't do the city tour the first day that I was in town, our guide Stuart was full of great suggestions on where to eat and what to do. Sadly I was leaving the next day and wasn't able to visit the great microbreweries that he recommended. I highly recommend that you do both tours if you have time.

amazing countryside tour of amsterdam. the title says it all. the weather was a bit iffy but our guide Petra kept us excited and entertained the entire time. she was crazy funny and her enthusiasm was infectious. instead of just listing facts and figures, she really made everything accessible by weaving it into a story so to speak. it honestly did not feel like 4hrs after everything was said and done.

Great way to experience Amsterdam. Our guide, Petra, was entertaining and awesome. She gave us the inside scoop on amsterdam and did a better job than the tour guide on our walking tour. We did the countryside bike trip and it was definitely worth it. My favorite part was visiting the cheese farm and tasting the cheese. I recommend buying the smoked Gouda, its soooo good.

Good way to see the countryside and eat some local cheese. We did the countryside tour for 4 hours. It was fun, you got to visit a cheese and clog making farm and see some demonstrations. Our guide was very enthusiastic which was great. If you're looking for local sights on this tour it's not really that, mostly it's a lot of biking (22km) with a few stops to chat about some history. I think they do a city tour though that would probably give more local info. Overall good value but be prepared for some biking!

A "MUST" for any trip to Amsterdam. My wife and I were only in Amsterdam for a day...May 19, 2011...but we decided to take the bike tour even though we have been to Amsterdam before. Wow...our guide Pete was not only deeply knowledgeable about the history of the city and country, but had a great sense of humor with great stories as well. With so many nooks and crannies, this is one of the best ways to understand what the city is all about. Especially since we are on bikes which probably out number cars by 25 to 1 in the city. It was not too strenuous and was great exercise over a few hours in the afternoon. We're already telling our friends about it back in the States!Thanks, Pete, it was awesome!B.J. & Kari
#great stuff#. What great way to learn about the city, good guide, lovely time, a must do

Awesome tour!. I did the countrside tour with my 2 brothers and we had a great time. We felt we'd seen enough of the city by walking so we opted for the country tour. It took about 4 hours total and covered 22 km. Our guide Stuart was great and full of interesting tidbits about Amsterdam and Holland. You do get to see a windmill and you go to a dairy farm - you don't actually see them making cheese but they do demonstrate how to make clogs. Really just an opportunity to buy some souveniers. The best part of the tour was just getting out of the city and enjoying the countrside and fresh air! Would definitely recommend to anyone visiting Amsterdam.

Best thing we did. You cannot go wrong with a Mike's Bike Tour. We did the 4-hour Country Tour. We are 2 adults (expert cyclists, road and mountain) and an 11-year-old strong boy, and a 14-year-old tentative girl. She's not a great cyclist. Man, if you're looking for a fun afternoon, and letting your testosterone chill, you're in for a great time. They do not take reservations. Show up at 11 am (not earlier), and they'll lead you across the street to a kind of warehouse where you'll hear a half-hour (maybe more) history talk about Amsterdam. Even if you know your history, it's fun and well done. We just sat on the floor and took it in. There were about 30 of us who showed up that day so after the talk we split into 2 groups (one with families; one not) and they set us up with bikes. This happened pretty quickly considering there were 30 people. The bikes were in good shape. They're 5-speed bikes, cruiser style bikes with front brakes (I learned that the brakes are on opposite handlebars in Europe, ie front wheels are controlled by the right hand...I digress) with adjustable seats. They also have a front saddle bag and rear paniers available so if your bike doesn't come with any, just ask. We carried our water bottles in them and the CLOGS my husband bought along the way. Seriously.We headed off around noon. Some people had forgotten how to ride bikes, but everything was pretty relaxed and everyone "got it". We meandered through the streets near the bike shop for around 15 minutes working our way out of the city. It's all flat except for the 1-minute bursts over canal bridges. This was my least favourite part as I worried about cars, street crossings, etc, but we did it. I should add that there were some younger kids too (age 7-8) and everyone managed just fine. Shortly we arrived along the banks of the Amstel River which was just gorgeous and we were truly in a rural area. This was on a rec path so we could let our guard down. Our first stop was by a windmill and that was a great photo op. Next stop: a clog factory and cheese factory farm....and gift shop! Ok, this is where it felt a bit tacky, but hey, we went along with it and the guy who spoke about his clog shop (demo-ed clog making) and talked about his cheese was fun and it was enjoyable. We were totally drawn in and bought a pile of souvenirs and cheese. The cheese was awesome and lasted for 2-weeks through the Italy leg of our trip! We learned that the airport prices for these same souvenirs like cheese graters was about 2/3 the price, but what the heck. This would have been a great place to have a picnic but they didn't sell other food besides cheese there. Tip: bring something like fruit, granola bar or a sandwich. We got really hungry but hung in there. The cycling continued along farm fields, onto rec paths, along an area where people live in houseboats, and finally through Vondel Park (like Central Park) and back onto the city streets. It was totally exhilarating and a feast for the eyes. Our bike guide was terrific and made sure the group stayed together. It was a very friendly atmosphere with like-minded travellers. We did so many cool things this trip (including hiking in Cinque Terre) but this was our total highlight.

What a fun day!. We, my husband and I along with a another couple, took the country side tour. We had a great time. We enjoyed all the stop breaks for the brief history lessons as well as the cheese farm/clog factory. Our guide was really personable and was super to our friend who is 6 months pregnant. I definitely would recommend this tour.

Should be called Grumpy Mike's!. The tour was a good way to see the city the way the locals do, and our tour guide (English guy whose name I can't remember) was great! However Mike himself and the other American guide were so grumpy and rude! Lighten up!

Top tour to get some culture!. We did Mike's Bike tour in Munich and decided we HAD to see what they had to offer in Amsterdam! We opted for the country-side tour since we were doing most of the city/red-light district stuff on our own and thought it sounded nice to get out of the city for a bit. It was a great decision! Pete was our guide and though he was quirky at times he really had a passion for Amsterdam and biking in general. He gave additional tips of self-guided tours we could do outside the city via the really great bike trails they have all throughout the Netherlands. On the tour though he was more that happy to take pictures of groups and in general make good attempts to get to know everyone and was approachable about advice on anything else Amsterdam related (where to go for food, nightlife, etc...) On the tour you head out of the city and (the main highlights) stop by an old-school windmill, a cheese and clog factory where you get samples and a really interesting demonstration of clog making. You go through some really nice parks and end up back in the city after about 4 hours! Definitely worth it if you're interested in getting out of the city for a bit!

The highlight of our Amsterdam weekend!. We had the most wonderful time on the Countryside bike tour! We lucked out with pretty amazing, sunny weather, and got to enjoy life outside of the city. We rode all over, including along the Amstel river, to a windmill and to a cheese farm/clog factory. We saw cows, deer, sheep, and the local Dutch just out enjoying their weekend. The bike ride itself was super easy--flat and with very comfortable bikes. The tour guides, Stuart and Petra, were very informative. They keep the groups down to max of 20 people and will form as many groups as needed. Petra was our guide and she was pretty wacky in a great way! She made everyone feel comfortable and interspersed all sorts of great stories and facts on Dutch history throughout the tour. This tour is a MUST for anyone in Amsterdam. Have fun!

Loved it!!!. We were in Amsterdam for our 22nd wedding anniversary - the first time we have been and loved this tour. We went on 28th April on the countryside tour and Peter was our guide. He was brilliant - very informative and enthusiastic - gave us lots of interesting facts every 15 minutes or so - we were then able to enjoy cycling without stopping all the time. We spent our first couple of days in the city centre which is easy to walk around if you are reasonably fit - we then enjoyed cycling on our last day away from the crowds. Enjoyed this tour so much - I came home and bought a bike!!!!

Such a great tour take it first day you get there.. Excellent tour. We were a little anxious as there is a ton of hustle and bustle biking through the city but it was actually really easy and relaxing for most part. Only regret we have is that we took the tour on our last day of the vacation rather than the first day because the tour helps you really get oriented on where everything is in the city. I forget our guide's name but she was really nice, informative, and pretty funny. It takes about 3 hours or so but it really feels like 30 minutes. Easily one of the best and most memorable parts of our trip would definitely take the countryside tour or a Mike's Bike tour in Germany or wherever else it's offered.

Mike's Bike Tour - MUST DO in Amsterdam!. Of our two weeks in Amsterdam, this was our most favorite. We took a walking tour of the city and a canal tour as well, but this is it! The Countryside bike tour was a great way to see what lay outside of Central Amsterdam. Stuart, our guide, was massively informative but more than that, hilarious with his quick wit and flavorful storytelling. You will only navigate the city streets for a few minutes, it's in no time that you reach the county roads and the clean, crisp air. We enjoyed the cheese farm and also got to see an example of dutch clogs being made. There were just enough stops along the ride for rest and fun facts. What was most wonderful, though, was the actual ride. The countryside is beautiful! If you are in Amsterdam for a short stay or a long holiday, this is my one recommendation to you. Carefree, easygoing and most of all - exactly what you want in a tour.

Awesome Experience!. Pete was our tour guide and there were approximately 25 people in our group. My wife and I had never been to Amsterdam and we really wanted to see the countryside and the city so we decided to take a bike tour with Mike's Bike Tours. It was so much fun to hear history about the city and the humor that Pete added into the tour. So, we got exercise on the 22 Kilometer ride, got to see a lot of the awesome countryside and canals of Amsterdam, stopped at a little cheese and a wooden shoe making factory. The cheese was outstanding and we had to buy some and bring it back with us to the UK. The wooden shoes were interesting and strange at the same time but I didn't buy any of those. We got to see an old windmill which was cool. We were lucky to have had great weather and I would recommend taking this countryside tour with this company!

Best day in Holland. I was a little afraid the riding bike with 7 and 4 years old kids, but it was easy and interesting for whole family. My youngest boy said that it was "Bublle day", because our guide Stiuart on the every corner was making bublles. The elder boy of 7 years did the trip very good, and after in the tour we take a chalenge to spent all afternoon on bikes in the center of amsterdam. Thanks a lot also for our companions - family from Swis and especially to our guide Stiuart who stays calm in every situation. I liked everything in this tour- history stories of amsterdam, lessons of driving bike in this crowdy town, silent view of districts.

Fabulous experience. Mike's Bike Tours is without a doubt the best way to see the Amsterdam countryside. Just show up at their Kerkstraat office at the appointed time of 11 am and off you go. The tour costs EUR 22.We had a wonderful guide in Stuart, who gave us a really exhaustive overview of the history of the city-a good place to start. He was friendly and knowledgeable and encouraged us to pick his brains with questions...For the countryside tour itself- it is really well structured. You bike outside the city seeing attractions such as the Skinny Bridge, a windmill, cheese and clog factory and the really gorgeous Dutch countryside. Its a great' everything in a nutshell 'kind of tour'. The clogs we bought in the farm were absolutely unique compared to the nonsense sold in the souvenir stores and the cheese was divine.Pray for a beautiful day -rain would probably be annoying on this ride. Luckily we got one and it was just perfect!HIGHLY recommended!

excellent way to explore the city. No doubt Amsterdam is a very bikable city. Joining the bike tour is the first thing we did on arrival to Amsterdam. Weather was excellent and the tour was very enjoyable. The guide gave us information about history and stories of Amsterdam which is very good for us to learn about this city. You also get to know the various locations better so it helps you to explore the city on your own afterwards. We found out that there is discount if you have the Iamsterdam card, but only on the next day! So, if you have "Iamsterdam card", be sure to present it as you pay and enjoy the discount. We did it on a Sat afternoon and traffic was very busy (lots of bikes and people on the road and bike lane). I think it would be better if you join on a weekday.

Best way to learn about Amsterdam's history and see the city. This tour was the most worthwhile thing you can do when you visit Amsterdam. Not only will you get a mini history lesson about Amsterdam's past, but you'll get a thorough tour of the city which will help you easily navigate during the rest of your stay. This is the perfect thing to do on your first day in town.My tour group consisted of myself, my girlfriend and one other person along with our guide, Stuart. We were surprised we still went on the tour with only 3 paying customers, but that made the experience even better. Stuart proved himself to be extremely knowledgeable about all things Amsterdam (history, culture, language, etc.).We hit a lot of the tourist spots as well as some lesser-known places. The highlight of the trip was our visit to a micro brewery called Brouwerij 't IJ, part of which is set into a windmill.The cost of the tour is 18 Euro and it was well worth the price.

definitely the best choice. I rented a bike for two days and also took the city tour. Our guide was an awesome guy named Stuart. He was so funny and knew interesting details about the city. The bike was comfortable and had a good quality. They have great rates compared to the other rental shops. Just don't miss the fun and have some time with these guys.

great way to see the city and the country. we spent only a couple of days in Amsterdam and wanted to see and do as much as we can. We picked to do the country tour as we already saw the city and wanted to experience the country without the car. Our guide was great and the bikes were really comfortable. I kind of felt like the locals on the bike and seeing the country, the windmill, the cheesefarm was a great experience. of course we bought a couple of cheese and also saw how the wooden clogs are made. I definately would suggest you to take the tour and it is really easy to bike around. I am close to 50 and my husband is over 50 , and we are not athletes.

Take a break from the busy city with the excellent countryside bike tour.. We visited Amsterdam for a weekend and decided that a guided bike tour would be a great way to experience the city like the locals do. As the city is so easy to get around on foot, we opted for the countryside tour and ended up having a fantastic afternoon out!The tour started off with Stuart, our guide, giving a brief but very interesting introduction to Dutch history and the origins of the city itself. Then we got a run down of bike basics and were sized up for a bike that fit (they cater for everyone!).The bikes themselves are a pretty simple city bike style and give a great, comfortable ride. They're all well maintained too and nobody had any problems in a group of 20, although the guide did have everything needed should anything have happened en route.Then the fun began! The tour starts off on some pretty quiet streets to get everyone used to their bikes, then it's off towards the outskirts and into the big beyond, with a few stops along the way to explain the local architecture and city design. It's not long before you're into open space and green fields along the Amsteldijk, making for a really pleasant cycle. From here on there's a stop off at a dairy farm to learn about cheese and clog production, a look at how the land is managed and then along some beautiful cycle tracks back into the centre via some of the city's main green areas. Stuart was incredibly knowledgeable and informative, but kept a good balance between cycling and info stops.All in all, this was an awesome way to spend a few hours getting away from the hectic city centre to see some of the Dutch countryside.

A brilliant way to see the city with a great guide. We were very aprehensive about cycling around the city on our own and on the 'wrong' side of the road at first, so decided to the safer option of a guided tour. This was the best decision we made!! The tour guide Stuart was brilliant. He knew everything about the city and made it funny and interesting. The tour was the best value for money activity we did. It lasted for four hours and we got to stop half way for a drink in an authentic Dutch pub. We really enjoyed it and it gave us the confidence to rent bikes the next day; we also got this at a discounted price because we had done the tour. All the staff that work in the shop are friendly and really helpful. They were there to answer all our questions and help us plan other activities we wanted to do. This is a great service and we would recommend it to anyone who visits the city. It's definitely suitable for everyone-you don't have to be a good cyclist. It's a must do!

Make sure you do this!. We took part in both the City and Countryside Tours on consecutive days. The City tour is great for orientating yourself in the city itself and see some of the sites. On the otherhand the countyside tour is a great chance to explore the surrounding countryside, canals, cheese and clog factories. Personally, I preferred the Countryside Tour but to be honest but are fantastic. Our guide was excellent and was also full of recommendations about restaurants and other sites in the city. I have taken similar tours in Paris and also plan a return visit this summer. I cannot recommend this highly enough. If you are brave enough you can also rent bikes from them at a discounted rate after you complete your tour and they give you a handy discount card for future tours with themselves or in Munich. Never fear if you dont think you are the fittest or not the best on a bike - Amsterdam is very flat and makes for an easy going way to spend the day..

Excellent service, great rates, good condition bike!. When I was in Amsterdam recently, I hired a bike from this company. The service was great, the lady explained how to work the bike lock easily and got a good quality bike. The rates were cheap, 10 Euros for the day and that included insurance. Only one very minor thing, my bike had a bright pink bell on it and got a couple of funny looks!

Best 3 hours I spent in Amsterdam, thanks to Stuart!. This was an awesome awesome bike tour. Stuart is an funny and knowledgeable English guy living in Amsterdam and doing the bike tours for fun (he's a chef by profession). We had a blast, couldn't have asked for a better tour and guide. This was easily the best money I spent while there. What a perfect afternoon!

Countryside bike tour is a must do!. Stuart, our guide, was great! He knew so much about the city and it's origins. He also knew quite a bit about how the city was engineered as well. Great guide! First he gave us an overview of the city and the history and then took us out and about. The farm he took us to was fantastic. I'm still nibbling on the great cheese we brought back with us. Our picture in front of the windmill will make a fantastic Christmas card. Thanks so much Mike's Bikes!!

Great countryside bike tour! Highly recommended!. I took a countryside bike tour! Really enjoyed it. You will feel like a local people there when you are riding a bike.  The British guide does know well about the city in terms of history; culture and funny stuffs as well. During the time i stayed in Amsterdam, i think he is the guy that i learned the most about Ams. He coulc answer all the questions about Ams, while other locals were always take time to think before answer my questions. Furthermore, if you have Iamsterdam card, you'll get 25% discount as well. Buy this card if you gonna take bike tour, canal cruise, visit museums, take trams, buses, metros..... This card definitely will save a lot of money for you! Highly recommend this bike tour!!! Once good thing, is you do not have to reserve in advance as well. If you take countryside tour, you'll visit Windmill, Cheese and Wooden Shoese factory, and can see deers, swans, cows....

Excellent!. You can see so much of the city on foot, the country tour is a great way to see parts of the 'dam you wouldn't normally.Learned a lot about the history of Holland, cheese, and wooden shoes. It was both interesting and fun! Would recommend to anyone who's looking for more than what city sights can offer - and our tour guides were perfect.

Great tour, good way to see th inner city of Amsterdam. Great tour, Stu was a great guide and so knowledgeable! Good value for money and the bikes are so comfy! would of liked to have time to do the country tour too, when we go back i will definitely do it! Thanks fellow trip advisors for your reviews as this is why we went with Mikes bike tours and will def recommend them!

Even a blast in the cold rain and wind!. We did the countryside tour because it started earlier in the day. Petra our guide was very fun and informative, we had crap weather, but it was worth it. Great ride, beautiful country and great guide. We learned a lot about Amsterdam and holland, had yummy cheese and bought wooden shoes. It was fun to see how the cheese and shoes were made! Next time I hope to do the city tour!

Excellent guide. I was in Amsterdam from Monday 18 Oct. till Thursday. The first thing I wanted to do was exploring the city by bike to view the highlights and to see what I should visit during my stay. Unfortunaltely, I was there alone on Monday, so the City Trip was cancelled :( They said it was only the third time this year that this happened. I went back Tuesday, and then there were enough others (I think we were 5 in total, plus the guide Petra). Unfortunately, the weather was not so good, and from time to time there were some raindrops.Before the start, we got a (not so brief) overview of the history of Amsterdam. We were told that Amsterdam did not grow spontaneously, but that the city layout was carefully planned, with all the canals and streets. It doesn't look like that to me: all these roads and waterways look so similar that it was like a labyrinth to me.But that was no problem for our guide that lead us to all the important buildings and places in town, accompanied with fun and entertaining explanations along the trip.One setback however: I wanted to keep a bike for the rest of my stay, so I needed to rent a different bike than the bikes that were used for the guided tour. The rental bikes come with a back pedal brake (like most Dutch bikes), instead of regular cantilever brakes. I find this strange, because the city is so busy with pedestrians and other bikes, that prompt reacting is sometimes needed, and that is easier with regular brakes. But that was not my main problem. The problem that got me fed up most, was that in 2 days time, the chain fell off at least 20 times! Of course this only happened after the guided tour, and after the shop was closed so I couldn't go back to get it repaired.But after all: a guided bike tour is really something one must do when visiting Amsterdam!

Would only change one thing, overall a good Amsterdam experience.. As a flight attendant I am often in cities for 24-48 hours and am able to do only a few activities at a time. I enjoy bikes tours as they provide a great way to see cities at a quicker pace than walking, but slower than a automobile tour. Mike's bike tour seemed to be the best bike tour for me in Amsterdam as I already had a bike and they give you 5 euros off the price if you bring your own bike. Most other sites I looked at did not give you that option. So my price was 13 Euro for the 2.5 hour city tour. At the start of the tour our guide gave us a run down of the city history and a how to bike in town lesson. Our actual time on the bikes in the city was about 2 hours. During this tour we stopped about 8 times to listen to our guide and ask questions. This was the only part I wish was a little better. I would have preferred more stopping with more information. When we did stop our guide was very knowledgeable. He was able to answer any questions we posed to him. At one time though we biked past the house where Anne Frank and her family hid, without stopping and without any word on it. I pointed it out the the people around me, thinking it was odd we didn't stop at what I would consider a very important place in town. Once back at the garage our guide gave us all resuturant recommendations and directtions to get home. The experice was a good one, I only wished things to be a little more informative. But for the price you couldn't beat Mike's. I plan on trying their country tour next time I am in town.To sum up: good value, knowledge guides, cover a lot of the city in short time, could have been a little more informative.

A very enjoyable and entertaining way to spend 3 or 4 hours. At first sight it all seems a bit chaotic down at Mikes Bikes.......However, once you get into the swing of it you soon realise they know what they are doing and really know how to show you round the city and surrounding countryside in an interesting (if not off-beat) way. Petra, our tour guide, instantly recognisable by her distinctive and frequent laugh , held all our attention and humorously provided some really interesting comments along with historical facts and figures all along the tour. Everyone finished the tour not only satisfied with the tour but with a smile !

Mike's Bikes made me feel Dutch!. I recently took the Amsterdam countryside bike tour with Mike's Bikes. It was about 4.5 hours and went outside of the city to a windmill and a wooden shoe maker/cheese farm and through a gorgeous park, alongside a canal. My guide, Pete, was VERY knowledgeable, really fun (he wore wooden shoes with tiger stripes painted on them!), and seemed genuinely interested in our group's wellbeing and enjoyment. I was nervous at first about the ride, as I'm not a regular bike rider, but the bikes were of high quality (cruisers with gears... mine was named Red Light Riley) and the ride was flat and smooth. I bought some authentic wooden shoes and fresh gouda on the ride. :) I would definitely recommend taking snacks and/or lunch, as there wasn't an official lunch stop (nor really anywhere to buy food, with the exception of the gouda). However, you could buy water at Mike's before departing. Next time I'm in Amsterdam, I'll try out their other tour or rent a bike from Mike's and venture out on my own. Highly recommended!!!!

Brilliant tour. Everything you ever wanted to know about Amsterdam and the Netherlands... and more!Starts with quick run down on the history of Amsterdam (brilliant)... off on the bikes heading out of town... you see a windmill... dykes... ridiculously flat land... a cheese farm... clogs being made... house boats... and probably loads more I can't remember right now... what more could you want???Incredibly knowledgeable guides... nice leisurely ride... it's a long ride, but not difficult since the land is so flat!Since the tour is mostly out of town, it's pretty chilled, not competing with trams/ tourists etc trying to gather round and hear the guide... a welcome break from the crazy city!
Really varied tour featuring all kinds of cool curiosities. Petra is the best bike guide ever! Her bubbles were a great idea and she's really fun.She can also fix a flat tire with godlike speed.

Great Tour. I took the countryside tour and would strongly advise for you to take this tour. My tour guide Petra was awesome very knowledgeble and entertaining. Alot of tours no matter what they are... are dependent on whether the tour guide brings the city to life and Petra with her friendly personality definatly brought Amsterdam to life..This was my first time in Amsterdam and only had one day to get to know the city and if there is one city you need to take a bike tour.. its in Amsterdam. A+On a side note... if you have small children make sure you bring your earplugs for them as she delivers some halarious raunchey jokes which I loved.. haha.

So fantastic, awesome, amazing... running out of words. everyone knows the tour guides make the tour.... this whole group is fantastic! We did the tour in Amsterdam and in Munich.... both so cool. They are so not the typical boring tour guides, they are fun, and you cant help but have a blast!

Essential in getting to know Amsterdam with plenty of laughs along the way. As a solo traveller I joined the country ride and found the staff to be extremely friendly with great senses of humour and enthusiastic about what they do. No booking required, I just rocked up at the nominated time and joined with a group of about 15 people for the tour. It rained a little and they provided ponchos for everyone. The tour is very informative, both from the guide and at the cheese factory and clog making. The guide even fixed my handbag for me when it broke! It's a fantastic way to spend a few hours, I'd recommend it to anyone!

Best thing I did in Amsterdam. As most people have said on here, the Mike's bike tour was the best thing I did on my 3 day trip to Amsterdam. I did the countryside tour, which starts at 11 AM, and goes on about a 23 kilometer trip through the countryside. You stop at a windmill, and also a cheese factory, and get to see wooden clogs being made. It was fun sampling the cheese. Our tour guide was great, he gave us a lot of history about Amsterdam. I didn't know that Amsterdam is like 30 feet below sea level, and the city uses a series of pumps to keep the water level at a consistent level - and the city never floods because of all of these pumps. There are photo stops at the windmill and at other spots along the way. I actually just had my camera out the whole time in my hand, and took pictures with one hand while riding the bike with the other, maybe not advised to do this unless you are on a flat road without other people around you. I'm in pretty good shape - the bike tour is definitely not completely easy, so if you are in really bad shape you might have a tough ride. Make sure if you are going over a canal bridge to ship to an easier gear, or you may not make it over the bridge. Also, watch out for crossing the street in the city, we had to cross the street without the guide a lot of the time. I would recommend doing the countryside tour instead of the city tour, because it is so nice to get out of the city and see the Amsterdam countryside away from more people. One other huge perk of Mike's bikes - if you go on one of their tours, you can rent a bike for really cheap the next day. I rented a bike the next day for 5 euro I think, and rode into the countryside again for another 25 kilometers or so, it was an awesome day.

One of the most memorable adventures in Europe.... with a great guide!. In the last three years I have traveled (not toured) 11 different countries in Europe with my 15 year old son, and anytime we experienced an unusual adventure that can familiarize an area I always write "tripadvisor" to inform other travelers. The city and countryside bike tours were fabulous, but what was most memorable was our guide "Pete'.... he upstaged the tours with his great personality. A MUST DO if in Amsterdam.Brad and Cody Winchendon, MA USA

Petra, the Wild Woman of Mike's Bike Tours!. It was so cool to have Petra, a blonde dreadlocked Dutch version of Crystal Bowersox, be our leader for the Countryside Bike Tour in July 2009! She looks like a Woodstock stoner throwback and has no prob letting you know what she will buy with her tip money! Very funny, very free young woman! The beginning of the tour was a bit hairy as she zips out of the shop into the AMS traffic fray;you really have to peddle to keep up PLUS keep your eye on the crazy bike/foot/vehicle traffic! But once we hit Vondelpark within 10 minutes, it was smooth sailing. You go from city to country SO FAST! I loved all the backways we took to get there. For the most part Petra knows here stuff (except in one instance where she said Nazis had Jewish prisoners help dig a rowing park--actually it was built before Nazi occupation). The cheese farm was a hoot (though smelly) and to finally see a windmill and to learn they are now preserved and none work anymore (the one we stopped at is a residence). Overall a great way to get a glimpse of the Dutch countryside and get some exercise too.

A very pleasant excursion. If you're going to Amsterdam and don't think you have the confidence to bike it round the city like the natives, then you should go on Mike's Bikes Countryside Tour - the only bits of city riding you have to do are getting out of and back into the city, but once you've been on the tour, you'll be confident enough to rent a bike for the rest of your stay!It rained heavily when we went on the countryside tour, but that didn't ruin an excellent few hours.I hadn't ridden a bike for ages before the tour, but the well timed stops, and the flat Dutch countryside ensured there were no problems keeping up!The guide was great, and the tour was good value for 22 euros including use of their bikes.

Mike's city tour. Peter The Great! That is Peter our guide gave a great tour. Just the right length and detail. And for the first time ever, I heard some one explain how to shift gears on a bike (I've always wondered about how people too afraid to ask survived without this knowledge. :)Good price, good way to learn Amsterdam history and The Best way to get around the city.

Countryside Tour was my highlight of Amsterdam. Great bike ride thru the outskirts of Amsterdam. It was a beautiful day and we stopped at a windmill, farm that tripled as a cheese and clog making factory, Vondelpark, and some other interest points. The tour was about 20 people and the tour guide was really knowledgeable. I loved it b/c I love being outdoors, getting exercise, doing what locals do (riding bikes), and I also I loved it b/c it took us out of the city into gorgeous countryside. Logistically, I liked that we didn't have to make a reservation - just simply show up! However, that creates some chaos at the beginning and it took a while to get everyone organized. But once we were on our way, things were smooth sailing. I definitely recommend this tour!

Countryside Tour is a welcomed break from the stereotypical Amsterdam. I planned a week trip for 12 "thirty-something" year old friends of mine to Europe this summer. They came from America and it was up to me to choose the best of Europe to show them. I sent them the itinerary ahead of time. First stop, Paris, the City of Lights. Next, a Wine Tasting on the Rhein River, followed by bicycle tour through the Dutch countryside in Amsterdam. Guess which one they couldn't wait to do. And the Mike's Bike tour lived up to the hype. We really enjoyed escaping all the busy streets of Amsterdam for one afternoon to see the land and people surrounding it. The ride is not at all strenous or tiring, the only uphills are small bridges that go over the canals! The cheese and clog factory are a nice rest, but a little over-touristic and cliche for my taste. My favorite part was the final stop in Vondelpark. Pete, our guide, was very friendly and knowledgable, and he proved that he can fix a flat tire in under 4 minutes! If you don't ride a bike while in Amsterdam, you will miss out on this iconic culture of the city.

Do not miss the City Tour of Amsterdam. We visited Amsterdam in late June. I had prebooked the city tour based on trip advisor reviews and was not disappointed. I was travelling with my 16 year old daughter she was quite nervous about riding in Amsterdam city as it looked busy from a pedestrian perspective. Pete our tour guide completely allayed her anxiety by his confident guidance and instructions and we thoroughly enjoyed our bike ride. I was thrilled with the comprehensive comentary given by Pete and by the diversity of the sights visited during the tour. We covered so much ground we could never have achieved this on our own or on foot. The bikes were really comfortable and easy to handle. It was great fun and a highlight of our stay in Amsterdam. I felt like I had really gotten to know the city a whole lot better than the average tourist by exploring the sidestreets with a local guide. Thumbs up to Mikes Bike City Tour!

awesome bike tour - find the real amsterdam. do the countryside tour over the city one so you can see the reall amsterdam, away from the sex and drugs. awesome bikes and guides, you go to a cheese and clog making factory, see the beuatiful lush green country side.definitely recommend it!

Very interesting bike ride !. Took the countryside tours with Mike's Bike Tours on a beautiful sunny day. It was great to ride the streets of Amsterdam and then get out to the surrounding countryside.Our guide, Pete, was absolutely amazing, and knew all the little details about Holland. I highly recommend this tour. And to make things even more interesting, after taking one of their tour, you get a 50% discount on a bike rental.

Makes for a nice day. I had one day in Amsterdam so I thought this bike tour would be perfect. It was, for the most part, but it's more biking than touring. I took the Munich tour and loved it...it was awesome. I enjoyed the Ansterdam version, but there were less stops, less narrative by the guide, and it seemed more of a bike ride than a tour. The Munich one felt like a tour, and was filled w/ really interesting information. I really enjoyed the Amsterdam Bike Tour, and had I not taken the Munich one before, I would probably rate this even higher. Perhaps there is less to see in Amsterdam than in Munich, or maybe the city tour (I took the country tour) is more fact filled. It was a lot of biking, which is fine, but some on the tour felt it was a little much (too long/strenuous).Overall very good, and a good way to see Amsterdam.

Great Tour. This was one of the highlights of Amsterdam for me. We took the countryside tour and were able go to a cheese and wooden clog place. It was a great experience and we had a great tour guide that was very informative. Luckily we had a very informative guide that taught us a lot about the area.

Walking is stupid. Ride a bike!. "Walking is stupid, ride a bike." That's their motto and it's true! I was incredibly impressed with this tour and the tour guide. The tour guide was filled with knowledge about Amsterdam and had a funny way of telling it. We were taken all over Amsterdam and even into the countryside to see a windmill and a dairy farm that makes cheese as well as wooden shoes! It is the best way to acclimate yourself to the city and see parts of the Netherlands that you wouldn't have seen otherwise!The only few things that I would say is, you need to be in fairly good shape to do this tour. If you haven't exercised in 5-to 10 years, you may find it not as enjoyable and/or you will hold the rest of the group back. Keep in mind that you will cover (I can't quite remember the distance now) I believe 10-12 miles on a bike. Also, BE AWARE OF THE BIKES!!!! :) Amsterdamers ride bikes. I am convinced that the people walking were all tourists! Just be prepared that when you leave Mike's Bike garage that you will need to be comfortable enough on a bike in order to dodge bikes, cars, people and trams. Once you get out of the city it isn't so bad. I loved this bike tour so much that I planned one in Brussels and in Paris. WORTH IT!!! I can't wait to take more bike tours! I will probably never walk through my vacations again! Thanks, Mike's Bikes!!!

Fun tour of the city. I had a great time doing the city tour. It's a great way to see the city, hear some of the stories, and just get out and have fun. I think it's less about doing a canned tourist tour than it is about experiencing the city as a local on a bike. We passed by all of the famous places in the city and even some places I hadn't heard about in all the tourist books. This bike trip really picked up my spirit and saved me from the routine of walking to museums and trying discover things on my own. A great time.

Walk Instead. Don’t take the city tour in early spring, wait until summer. All you will get is cold rain—not worth it. The weather aside, after being on five bikes tours in five different major European cities, this one is at the bottom of the list. After the first hour on the tour you realize all of Amsterdam practically looks and smells (marijuana) the same—canals and row homes. This tour was constantly intersecting major thoroughfares and cross walks, constantly making the bike rider play ‘dodge the pedestrian’—not enjoyable. The guide didn’t use age appropriate language/humor. Several kids were on our tour and the guide did not curtail his language or discussion of many adult topics—awkward. Do your research; skip the bike tour and the canal boat tours (major rip-offs). Find out the major historical points of the town, WALK to them, look around, eat something and leave. You will have a much better experience of this city.

Start your Amsterdam break with this tour, absolutely brilliant. We are so glad that we did this tour, it was the best thing about our whole week in Amsterdam. Our guide Peter was very knowledgeable about the history of this fantastic city, giving a clear and entertaining potted version before the tour actually starts. The bikes are very confortable and even someone like me, a very occasional rider, did not find the tour at all challenging. You do have to keep your eyes out and ears peeled for cars, trams, buses, pedestrians and especially other cyclists. However, doing this tour gives you a glimpse of what it might actually be like to belong to the Amsterdam cycling community.Each section of the tour only involves cycling for ten minutes at the most, and you know that Amsterdam is flat, so no problems with fatigue. There is plenty of time to take in the sights and sounds of each district. Peter gave us loads of information on the history of various areas, and the best things to see. Because of his tips we went to the top floor cafe of the new Library building near the station. He said that we would 'have the best views of the city', and he was right! We also visited the marvellous Horticultural Gardens, a marvellous tranquil space that would be enjoyable for non-gardeners too.Just telephone the office and they will tell you when the next tour is leaving, no booking required. I would highly recommend this to anyone.

Depends on which tour guide you get. After reading all of the reviews for this tour I was certain we'd have an amazing time. But we were disappointed. Our tour guide for the countryside tour was irritating and kept laughing hysterically at her own awful jokes. Her gags were so bad I was embarrassed for her. She made very off-colour comments that made everyone uncomfortable. I know its Amsterdam and 'anything goes' but she crossed the line on several occasions. I guess its the luck of the draw. The scenery is beautiful and the cheese factory was cool so if you get a good guide you'll have a great time.

Best part of our trip to Amsterdam!. My husband and I took the City Tour while on vacation. Stuart was our tour guide. It was, without a doubt, the best sightseeing we did in the city! I was a little nervous about riding through the streets of Amsterdam during rush hour on a Friday, but it was easier than expected - as long as you watch where you are going. Stuart introduced us to the basic history of the city and its culture. It was very laid back, fun, and informational - not like a guided museum tour. He also gave the group some fantastic recommendations for food and other activities throughout the city. We took his advice on everything except the St. Nicholas boat rides...only because we ran out of time. We loved the tour so much, the fat tire tour (affiliated with Mike's) in Berlin a few days later!

Best Part of Amsterdam. My wife and I went on the countryside tour the last week of May and had a blast. We had a little bit of trouble finding Mike's outpost within the city, but eventually we got there and we are so glad we did.Admittingly, we had some doubts about our abilities on the bikes through the city, but made it through with no problems. I even felt like a local, even though I'm sure I looked nothing of the sort. After a brief ride through town, we made it to a relaxing road with little traffic where my wife and I could ride two abreast. We took in the scenery and enjoyed our guide's talks at various stops.I loved the cheese farm where we got to try some fresh cheese, see how it is made and also witness the creation of a clog from block to foot. The farmer is great and made the tour very enjoyable. We even got to stop for a refreshing Heineken half-way through...Our ride back through the main park (Vondel...something or other) was fabulous and when we finally got back, I didn't want to get off. The guide gave some background on the future of the city's leniencies which was very informative. All in all, the best experience that you could do in Amsterdam.

Highlight of our short 2 days in Amsterdam. We did the countryside tour and brought our own bikes because we stayed a bit further away from their location. Our guide Stewart was excellent. Definitely enjoyed it and would recommend doing this tour if you've only got a short time in Amsterdam. He gave us good tips and recommendations of places to eat and other things to see in and around Amsterdam too.

Went home and bought the bike!. A group for friends and myself when on the City Bike tour near the end of our trip and I wish we would have done it first thing. You learn so much and the guide (Stuart) was the best at pointing out the best food, the best sites, etc. in Amsterdam. The tour was 3 hours and the pace was very good. We stopped often as he describe various aspects of Amsterdam in humorous detail. Riding a bike in Amsterdam is a bit crazy and you might be afraid at first but overall it wasn't too bad. I loved the bike we used so much I bought one when I returned home. They are the most comfortable bikes ever! I could have went another 3 hours easily!

Favorite thing we did! Stuart rocks.. My friend and I went on a bike tour, Friday 14th with Stuart of Mike's Bikes. We did the country tour and went to the see the windmill and farm. It was so fun! Stuart was just great....he told us about the history of the country, gave us an insight into living in Amsterdam and was generally just fun. I highly, highly recommend the tour and the company. They have personality and really seem to enjoy their jobs...and for $22 you can't beat it it! Stuart also told us about the St. Nicholas boat tour which we did later in the week. It's also a must if you can fit it in.

Highly recommend!. We did the countryside tour and had a great time. We brought along our 2 year old son and had no problems fitting him into the baby carrier or with the pace of the ride. The guide, Peeta I think her name was, and the guys in the shop were very friendly and helpful.

Such a good use of 4 hours in a new city. My friend and I took the countryside bike tour on a Saturday in late April. It was one of my favorite activities of the trip. Our guide, Stewart, was very knowledgeable about the city and it was a good balance of information and biking, soaking in the sights. I found biking within the city quite stressful, but on the countryside tour they take fairly straightforward routes in and out that minimize that stress. We had a small group and were able to meet other travelers that we hung out with later. I cannot say enough good things about this experience.

Great way to see Amsterdam.. There's no better way to get used to all the bikes in Amsterdam than to hop on one yourself. Took the city tour in January and immediately had a good orientation to the city and its top sites. That was really valuable given that I was going to be in town for a week. I've done bike tours in other European cities and this was pretty standard fare -- an ex-pat American extols the great parts of the city while dissing the US. No surprises here -- had Mike who told lots of stories about his love of the cafes (and his displeasure with US policy on weed) and his preferred choice of prostitutes. I could have done without all that. But still love the tour and highly recommend it to everyone.

Our family's unanimous favorite activity in Amsterdam. My husband and I took our two boys (ages 7 and 8) on a Mike's Bike tour during our 3 day trip to Amsterdam. What a great time we had! Before we left, I was a little apprehensive because our 7 year-old hasn't yet learned to ride a bike. But Mike's Bikes referred us to MacBike for a bike rental in this case. There, we rented a bike with a large basket in front for our son to sit in. My husband drove him around (it was a little unwieldy, but it worked!). We started out going through the city for just a short while. Our tour guide was great--informative and humorous. We chose the countryside bike tour because I wanted a longer ride and really didn't care for a detailed drive-through and description of the red light district with my sons. I am so glad we went this route. Apparently, it's a 12 mile round trip, but it didn't feel long. My 8 year-old did great and we really enjoyed cycling out in the countryside where it was open and stress-free. The trip lasted about 3 1/2 hours with stops at a windmill and cheese and clog factory. Very neat!Definitely bring a camera. We brought our Flip camcorder and my 7 year-old had fun making some videos while riding in the basket. I would do this tour again in a heartbeat!

Great outing. We took the country tour with Pete as our guide. He was very informative, making the outing very enjoyable. Before we departed, he and another guide, Stewart, gave us a good insight into the history of Amsterdam and the surrounding area. The riding pace was leisurely with frequent stops for explanations of the sights. The people on the tour aged from about 7 years to 60+ and everyone found it enjoyable. We stopped at a farm that produces cheese and makes wooden shoes as well.We would recommend this to people of any age who want to see a bit of Amsterdam and the county side as well.

GREAT GREAT.. We had 2 tours, first the city tour, and the next day the country tour.We had Peter as a guide and he is awesome, the tour are in a very relaxed speed, so every one can follow them.I really recomend this.

Add a thouroughly enjoyable fitness element to your Amsterdam visit.. Mikes Bike Tours country tour leaves at 11am. You can easily walk there from your city hotel and within a few minutes be riding a great bike around the city--just like the locals. Our tour guide was Mike, who gave us an excellent synopsis of Dutch history, followed by an often humorous, always insightful, introduction to current life. Because the terrain is flat, and because we stopped at scenic points along the way, our entire group easily finished the ride which must have been about 15 miles in about 4 hours. Even grade school aged kids and older types like me made it. My daughter and I thought it was easily the most fun and memorable tour we've taken in a long time. The adult bikes were new 7 speed electra townies in great shape and easy to pedal, comfy seats. From this wonderful perch we saw canals, a windmill, country and city life, a farm with cows you can pet.

no problem at all for the kids. We arrived in Amsterdam and decided to take bike tour to get oriented to the city. These people couldn't have been more accomodating. We arrived breathless and late without reservations and with our 9 and 11 year old daughters. We knew our kids could handle the ride, we are fairly active, but not ultra sporty. 11 year old is a year round swimmer, 9 year old plays tennis once a week and summer swimmer.
